posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: The topic of robot reliability and it’s championship winning potential has been discussed at length on this website. However, I couldn’t find a specific thread on here related to reliability on the software end. So, how do teams create robust software, what testing methods (physical robot testing, unit tests, sims or even static analysis) do teams use? Furthermore, how do teams handle errors when they come up to attempt to reduce their scope  and fix them later. I’ve seen the common recommendations of how to reduce electrical and mechanical risk, but not many on making your software bulletproof.

Standard software practices apply

don’t trust inputs to functions. Always range check your inputs

Handle error conditions appropriately, don’t just code for the happy path

Avoid potentially unending loops in your code. Example a loop based on sensor input. In fact avoid unnecessary loops all together if you can.

avoid “cute” expressions, where people try to condense code into an unreadable single line.

Using meaningful naming conventions, comments, and indentation. Make your code readable

Use source control

Require code reviews on code checkin

Write unit tests for individual functions

don’t write super long functions

Read and understand code and libraries from 3rd parties

Be careful if updating dependencies, run unit tests afterwards

Learn to use the profiler and debugger

Use simulation along with unit tests to verify code

Set warnings as compilation errors

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked:
Imo, this comes down to 2 main things:

Simulation - if you can simulate your code, you can test it against pretty much anything. Scenarios that would be hard / risky to create on the robot. If your code fully works in sim (bonus if it’s a direct motor sim, like CTRE ’s sim), then there are pretty much no logic errors to be had on the real robot. There may be some, of course, but most of it (and maybe all of it) will be found in sim, the only thing left on the robot being calibrations.

Readability and clean code - if you follow a specific set of code rules, extract to as many functions as possible, and create easy to understand code (and I’m not talking about comments. The code itself should express intent), you’re going to create code where the problems are pretty obvious. And when they do show up, you’ll solve them easily.

In the end, your code will probably never work perfectly first try. To create bulletproof code, just test and use your robot as much as possible (in sim, or IRL).

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked:
Something im surprised not to have seen mentioned already is just running the code. Before this year we put tons of time and effort into our code each year but without fail… some problem would crop up at our first regional that required getting a CSA on the horn.

Have programmers on standby when your driver is getting his practice, note whats broken and dedicate time to fixing it.

Similarly, keep code within your reach. Some of the best robots ever driven were less than 100 lines long code wise, but every bit of them was rigorously tested. Remember, all the advance features in the world wont help you when you have to sit out a match because your auto failed to load right.

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
Here are some things we try to do to minimize risk:

Have on-boot procedures (both automated in software and performed by the drive team before a match) to verify that all hardware and software components are running as expected.

Implement a soft code freeze policy in the days leading up to competition, where the significance of a change is weighed against the remaining time to rigorously test it. This includes not updating third-party libraries unless there’s a known bugfix we need.

Have a known working configuration of the software before attending the competition.

Don’t make changes to the known working software configuration at competition unless absolutely necessary, and have a process for multiple people to review and sign off on changes if they are made. Triple-check that any changes are being made on the correct software branch, and only deploy committed code to the robot to avoid not knowing what code was on the robot for a past match.

Never deploy code at competition if there is no time to run a systems test before the next match.

posts.name: Zach Pascual
posts.cooked:
Eugene_Fang:

Don’t make changes to the known working software configuration at competition unless absolutely necessary

What abt that climber addition at SVR on Sunday?

Our methodology:

Prior to every match, after mechanical and electrical checks, the driver(s)/pit software will do a systems check to verify all systems.

A hard 3rd party code freeze and a soft “managed” code freeze.

We do a release/tag on github prior and post every comp

Run our competition version of code for a week straight with only minor tweaks prior to comp.

Never deploy code at comp unless we can run an exaggerated systems check

We have 2 automatic checks prior for a PR to be merged: build of code (github build) and formatting

Most errors are caught by running the bot non stop during driver practice 1 week prior to comp, but if something happens unexpectedly, we pull logs and usually things are pretty clear as to what went wrong (i.e. cycle times were really long - happened to us all year or something else)

Without sim, we had to purely brute force and test constantly to make our code as “bullet proof” as possible. Each auto was tested extensively and tracked (like most of our metrics) in a google sheet so we can see what we need to improve image 3510×492 263 KB

image 3510×492 263 KB

image 3510×492 263 KB

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
You asked for “robust practices” akin to mechanical/electrical tips and tricks (like hot-gluing everything). So here’s my take on something like that for software.

This is where language choice and language features can have an impact.

You get some “Static Analysis” for “free” when you use compiled languages such as Java and C++, inherent in the type system. Leveraging this type system can make software more robust.

The basic idea is you write code such that if there were a logic error, the compiler will catch it.

A really shining example of this is the C++ units library (and I’m sure the Java units library to a similar extent).

A large class of errors you could have is thinking a floating point variable is one unit when its actually another (e.g. ft or meters). You could try to combat this with diligent variable names.

Now, maybe when the code was written, getDistanceToSpeaker() returned a value in feet, but maybe someone refactors the vision code to use a different pose estimator and now it calculates things in meters. They might even realize this change and tried to fix it everywhere, but maybe this code exists on a parallel git branch to the refactor, so they get merged.

This code will now be erroneous and it might not even be obvious except for a mid-range of distances (really close and really far might end up aiming to a similar angle), so it may be hard to track down.

You can change this to use a unit-aware type which looks like this in C++

If getDistanceToSpeaker() returns a different unit, the compiler will automatically and correct convert it for you. If getDistanceToSpeaker() returns a raw float, the code won’t compile, and the user will be directed to fix it by explicitly declaring in code what unit-type to use, hopefully by modifying getDistanceToSpeaker

A lot of beginner programmers see compiler errors as a hindrance, something preventing them from being productive, but what I try to instill is that the code IS wrong, and the compiler just told you why without you having to go through the trouble of deploying it to a live robot.

Similarly, I recommend enabling compiler warnings and having them be considered errors (-Wall -Werror). Not sure what the Java equivalent is. I’ve had a lot of crashes and sometimes infinite loops that were pointed out by ignored warnings.

posts.name: Eugene Fang
posts.cooked:
zpascual:

What abt that climber addition at SVR on Sunday?

We score zero pieces and lose 3 matches in a row .

Don’t make changes mid-comp, kids.

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: Oh dear If have seen your reply before this season, our team would have performed SOOOOO much better…

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Asher Olgeirson:

create robust software

This is a great list by @LPryor that helps show that good software is created and you can’t just test-in quality. More specific examples for some items:

LPryor:

don’t trust inputs to functions. Always range check your inputs

Below was posted recently and I immediately pointed my camera on a steady tripod at an AprilTag on the wall. Within a few minutes I got 4 bad margins for a good tag and a tag number 700 something. So much for thinking you can ignore 1 in a million.

I know this sounds dumb but thoughts on wrapping robot code in a try catch

Last year our robot disabled during a crucial match because of a 1 in a million error. Some how our limelight saw ApriTag 157 , and it caused an index out of bounds error that crashed our robot.

LPryor:

Handle error conditions appropriately, don’t just code for the happy path

Repeating my advice from that thread - check for error conditions from libraries. All the motor controller functions return a status code directly or if they return another value then check the global status function return. Restart failed attempts

LPryor:

Avoid potentially unending loops in your code.

but limit that restart loop to a reasonable number like 5.

Add a timer to loops that you have to have but can’t put on a limiting counter.

LPryor:

avoid “cute” expressions, where people try to condense code into an unreadable single line.

The java var was added to the language to encourage (lazy?) programmers to split too long statements. You don’t have to code this type but do split long statements. var might help to indicate this variable is a “temporary” one.

LPryor:

Using meaningful naming conventions, comments, and indentation. Make your code readable

Repeating the often made advice - think, code in the problem space and not the solution space. Use if (gamePieceInPosition) and not if (dio1) . Doing so has another benefit of being able to eliminate many code comments that likely weren’t made anyways.

Another point is refactor code immediately upon thinking of a better way or better variable name or better comment or better algorithm.

Also, remove “dead” commented out code from in-line soon after testing its better replacement code. If you don’t dare to delete code after it’s been replaced, then move it to the bottom of the file. Better yet may be to take advantage of the github/VSCode history to be able to resurrect old code if need be.

It’s all about making code easy to read by eliminating all the distractions even if those distractions broke your concentration for only milliseconds.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Meche, not software, but from my limited knowledge, KISS is very much a thing here as well. Don’t overcomplicate, it’s a lot easier to debug 100 lines than 1000 lines. As with mechanical, the simpler something is, the easier it is to work with and get effectively working.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.cooked: Very much so - professionally I have put a stop to a lot of young developers making cute overly complex code that’s hard to maintain.  It all applies to robotics.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

Repeating the often made advice - think, code in the problem space and not the solution space. Use if (gamePieceInPosition) and not if (dio1) . Doing so has another benefit of being able to eliminate many code comments that likely weren’t made anyways.

This is the most important skill for a programmer.  Comments should only be used when it isn’t practical to write the code to read like what it does.  It is almost always possible.

Remember, too, that a large project has multiple “levels” of problem-space and solution-space - the solution-space of one layer may be the problem-space of another.  Be intentional about which level your language is relative to - it depends on who you expect to be stuck using your signifiers .  The “problem space” of a logging utility may be the “solution space” of the telemetry code that uses it, for example.  The naming conventions in public and private methods should usually be somewhat different, for this reason.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
Eugene_Fang:

Don’t make changes mid-comp

It was a running joke at champs this year for us to have fresh code on the robot each match. After our robot had issues in our first qual we probably pushed altered code before each of the next several  matches.

While I wish we didn’t have to do this and we got very lucky we didn’t seriously break something, we still jokingly blame issues that arise in matches from stale code.
